lines.text: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, HERO, BEATRICE, and Attendants

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Come, Friar Francis, be brief only to the plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: To be married to her: friar, you come to marry her.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: I do.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not be conjoined, charge you, on your souls, to utter it.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Know you any, Hero

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: None, my lord.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Know you any, count

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I dare make his answer, none.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: O, what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do, not knowing what they do!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: How now! interjections Why, then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Stand thee by, friar. Father, by your leave: Will you with free and unconstrained soul Give me this maid, your daughter

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And what have I to give you back, whose worth May counterpoise this rich and precious gift

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Nothing, unless you render her again.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Sweet prince, you learn me noble thankfulness. There, Leonato, take her back again: Give not this rotten orange to your friend Shes but the sign and semblance of her honour. Behold how like a maid she blushes here! O, what authority and show of truth Can cunning sin cover itself withal! Comes not that blood as modest evidence To witness simple virtue Would you not swear, All you that see her, that she were a maid, By these exterior shows But she is none: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: What do you mean, my lord

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Not to be married, Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof, Have vanquishd the resistance of her youth, And made defeat of her virginity,

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I know what you would say: if I have known her, You will say she did embrace me as a husband, And so extenuate the forehand sin: No, Leonato, I never tempted her with word too large But, as a brother to his sister, showd Bashful sincerity and comely love.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: And seemd I ever otherwise to you

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it: You seem to me as Dian in her orb, As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown But you are more intemperate in your blood Than Venus, or those pamperd animals That rage in savage sensuality.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Sweet prince, why speak not you

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: What should I speak I stand dishonourd, that have gone about To link my dear friend to a common stale.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: This looks not like a nuptial.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: True! O God!

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Leonato, stand I here Is this the prince is this the princes brother Is this face Heros are our eyes our own

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: All this is so: but what of this, my lord

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Let me but move one question to your daughter And, by that fatherly and kindly power That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: O, God defend me! how am I beset! What kind of catechising call you this

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: To make you answer truly to your name.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Is it not Hero Who can blot that name With any just reproach

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Marry, that can Hero Hero itself can blot out Heros virtue. What man was he talkd with you yesternight Out at your window betwixt twelve and one Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: I talkd with no man at that hour, my lord.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Why, then are you no maiden. Leonato, I am sorry you must hear: upon mine honour, Myself, my brother and this grieved count Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night Talk with a ruffian at her chamberwindow Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain, Confessd the vile encounters they have had A thousand times in secret.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Fie, fie! they are not to be named, my lord, Not to be spoke of There is not chastity enough in language Without offence to utter them. Thus, pretty lady, I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been, If half thy outward graces had been placed About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart! But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! farewell, Thou pure impiety and impious purity! For thee Ill lock up all the gates of love, And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang, To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm, And never shall it more be gracious.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Hath no mans dagger here a point for me
HERO swoons

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light, Smother her spirits up.
Exeunt DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: How doth the lady

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Dead, I think. Help, uncle! Hero! why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand. Death is the fairest cover for her shame That may be wishd for.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: How now, cousin Hero!

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Have comfort, lady.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Dost thou look up

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Yea, wherefore should she not

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing Cry shame upon her Could she here deny The story that is printed in her blood Do not live, Hero do not ope thine eyes: For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die, Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames, Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches, Strike at thy life. Grieved I, I had but one Chid I for that at frugal natures frame O, one too much by thee! Why had I one Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggars issue at my gates, Who smirchd thus and mired with infamy, I might have said No part of it is mine This shame derives itself from unknown loins But mine and mine I loved and mine I praised And mine that I was proud on, mine so much That I myself was to myself not mine, Valuing of her,why, she, O, she is fallen Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea Hath drops too few to wash her clean again And salt too little which may season give To her foultainted flesh!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Sir, sir, be patient. For my part, I am so attired in wonder, I know not what to say.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: O, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No, truly not although, until last night, I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Confirmd, confirmd! O, that is stronger made Which was before barrd up with ribs of iron! Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie, Who loved her so, that, speaking of her foulness, Washd it with tears Hence from her! let her die.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Hear me a little For I have only been silent so long And given way unto this course of fortune. ... By noting of the lady I have markd A thousand blushing apparitions To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames In angel whiteness beat away those blushes And in her eye there hath appeard a fire, To burn the errors that these princes hold Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool Trust not my reading nor my observations, Which with experimental seal doth warrant The tenor of my book trust not my age, My reverence, calling, nor divinity, If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here Under some biting error.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Friar, it cannot be. Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left Is that she will not add to her damnation A sin of perjury she not denies it: Why seekst thou then to cover with excuse That which appears in proper nakedness

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Lady, what man is he you are accused of

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: They know that do accuse me I know none: If I know more of any man alive Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant, Let all my sins lack mercy! O my father, Prove you that any man with me conversed At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight Maintaind the change of words with any creature, Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Two of them have the very bent of honour And if their wisdoms be misled in this, The practise of it lives in John the bastard, Whose spirits toil in frame of villanies.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I know not. If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her if they wrong her honour, The proudest of them shall well hear of it. Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine, Nor age so eat up my invention, Nor fortune made such havoc of my means, Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends, But they shall find, awaked in such a kind, Both strength of limb and policy of mind, Ability in means and choice of friends, To quit me of them throughly.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Pause awhile, And let my counsel sway you in this case. Your daughter here the princes left for dead: Let her awhile be secretly kept in, And publish it that she is dead indeed Maintain a mourning ostentation And on your familys old monument Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites That appertain unto a burial.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: What shall become of this what will this do

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf Change slander to remorse that is some good: But not for that dream I on this strange course, But on this travail look for greater birth. She dying, as it must so be maintaind, Upon the instant that she was accused, Shall be lamented, pitied and excused Of every hearer: for it so falls out That what we have we prize not to the worth Whiles we enjoy it, but being lackd and lost, Why, then we rack the value, then we find The virtue that possession would not show us Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio: When he shall hear she died upon his words, The idea of her life shall sweetly creep Into his study of imagination, And every lovely organ of her life Shall come apparelld in more precious habit, More movingdelicate and full of life, Into the eye and prospect of his soul, Than when she lived indeed then shall he mourn, If ever love had interest in his liver, And wish he had not so accused her, No, though he thought his accusation true. Let this be so, and doubt not but success Will fashion the event in better shape Than I can lay it down in likelihood. But if all aim but this be levelld false, The supposition of the ladys death Will quench the wonder of her infamy: And if it sort not well, you may conceal her, As best befits her wounded reputation, In some reclusive and religious life, Out of all eyes, tongues, minds and injuries.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you: And though you know my inwardness and love Is very much unto the prince and Claudio, Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in this As secretly and justly as your soul Should with your body.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Being that I flow in grief, The smallest twine may lead me.

lines.speaker: friar francis
lines.text: Tis well consented: presently away For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure. Come, lady, die to live: this weddingday Perhaps is but prolongd: have patience and endure.
Exeunt all but BENEDICK and BEATRICE

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I will not desire that.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: You have no reason I do it freely.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right her!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Is there any way to show such friendship

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: A very even way, but no such friend.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: May a man do it

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: It is a mans office, but not yours.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I do love nothing in the world so well as you: is not that strange

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: As strange as the thing I know not. It were as possible for me to say I loved nothing so well as you: but believe me not and yet I lie not I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sorry for my cousin.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Do not swear, and eat it.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I will swear by it that you love me and I will make him eat it that says I love not you.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Will you not eat your word

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest I love thee.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Why, then, God forgive me!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: What offence, sweet Beatrice

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: You have stayed me in a happy hour: I was about to protest I loved you.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: And do it with all thy heart.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Come, bid me do any thing for thee.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Kill Claudio.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Ha! not for the wide world.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I am gone, though I am here: there is no love in you: nay, I pray you, let me go.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Beatrice,

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: In faith, I will go.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Well be friends first.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Is Claudio thine enemy

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman O that I were a man! What, bear her in hand until they come to take hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated rancour, O God, that I were a man! I would eat his heart in the marketplace.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Hear me, Beatrice,

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Nay, but, Beatrice,

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Sweet Hero! She is wronged, she is slandered, she is undone.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Beat

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Princes and counties! Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly count, Count Comfect a sweet gallant, surely! O that I were a man for his sake! or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into courtesies, valour into compliment, and men are only turned into tongue, and trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged Hero

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Enough, I am engaged I will challenge him. I will kiss your hand, and so I leave you. By this hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go, comfort your cousin: I must say she is dead: and so, farewell.
Exeunt
